facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 408-409 of 1964 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 408-409 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 5, 1963 of the Rajasthan High Court in D.B. Civil Writ Petitions Nos. 172 and III of 1961.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from judgment and order dated February 5, 1963 of Rajasthan High Court in D.B. Civil Writ Petitions Nos. 172 and 111 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 5, 1963 of the Rajasthan High Court in D.B. Civil Writ Petitions Nos. 172 and III of 1961. C. Kosliwal, Advocate-General, for the State of Rajasthan, K. K. Jain and R. N. Sachthey, for the appellant.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court allowed Civil Writ Petitions Nos. 111 and 172 of 1961 and quashed orders imposing penalties on respondent Ghasilal for delay in payment of tax due.

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals by special leave are directed against the judgment of the Rajasthan High Court allowing Civil Writ Petitions Nos. 111 and 172 of 1961, and quashing orders of the Sales Tax authorities imposing penalties on the respondent, Ghasilal, for delay in payment of tax due.

facts.text: Rajasthan Sales Tax Rules published in Rajasthan Gazette on March 28, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts are these. On March 28, 1955, Rajasthan Sales Tax Rules  hereinafter referred to as the Rules  were published in the Rajasthan Gazette. The Rajasthan Sales Tax Act  hereinafter referred to as the Act  came into force on April 1, 1955.

facts.text: Rajasthan Sales Tax Act came into force on April 1, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The Rajasthan Sales Tax Act  hereinafter referred to as the Act  came into force on April 1, 1955. The respondent filed Civil Writ Petition, No. 11 of 1958, in the High Court challenging the making of assessments on the turnover of the respondent for the year 1955-56 on the ground that the said Rules were invalid.

facts.text: Respondent filed Civil Writ Petition No. 11 of 1958 challenging assessments for 1955-56 on ground Rules invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed Civil Writ Petition, No. 11 of 1958, in the High Court challenging the making of assessments on the turnover of the respondent for the year 1955-56 on the ground that the said Rules were invalid. On January 9, 1958, the High Court passed an interim order that the petitioner will keep proper accounts and file the prescribed returns but he shall number be assessed till further orders.

facts.text: On January 9, 1958, High Court passed interim order that petitioner keep proper accounts, file prescribed returns but not be assessed till further orders.

anchor.surface_text: On January 9, 1958, the High Court passed an interim order that the petitioner will keep proper accounts and file the prescribed returns but he shall number be assessed till further orders. While the petition was pending in the High Court, an Ordinance  No. 5 of 1959  was promulgated on November 6, 1959, validating the Rules.

facts.text: Ordinance No. 5 of 1959 promulgated on November 6, 1959 validating the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: While the petition was pending in the High Court, an Ordinance  No. 5 of 1959  was promulgated on November 6, 1959, validating the Rules. Thereupon the respondent withdrew Writ Petition No. 1 1 of 195 8.

facts.text: Respondent withdrew Writ Petition No. 11 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the respondent withdrew Writ Petition No. 1 1 of 195 8. On December 17, 1959 the Rajasthan Sales Tax Validation Act  Rajasthan Act 43 of 1959  replaced the Ordinance.

facts.text: Rajasthan Sales Tax Validation Act (Rajasthan Act 43 of 1959) on December 17, 1959 replaced the Ordinance.

anchor.surface_text: On December 17, 1959 the Rajasthan Sales Tax Validation Act  Rajasthan Act 43 of 1959  replaced the Ordinance. It is companymon ground that the effect of the said Ordinance and the said Act was to validate the Rules, even if any defect existed in the making of the Rules.

facts.text: Effect of Ordinance and Act was to validate the Rules; common ground.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the effect of the said Ordinance and the said Act was to validate the Rules, even if any defect existed in the making of the Rules. We may mention that according to the appellant, the said Ordinance and the said Validating Act were enacted out of abundant caution.

facts.text: Appellant contends Ordinance and Validating Act enacted out of abundant caution.

anchor.surface_text: We may mention that according to the appellant, the said Ordinance and the said Validating Act were enacted out of abundant caution. On December 4, 1959, the Sales Tax Officer, Kotah City Circle, sent a show cause numberice to the respondent in the following words Your writ No. 11 has been dismissed by the Honble High Court on 23rd November, 1959.

facts.text: On December 4, 1959, Sales Tax Officer, Kotah City Circle sent show cause notice to respondent stating writ No.11 dismissed on 23rd November 1959, deposit tax within a week.

anchor.surface_text: On December 4, 1959, the Sales Tax Officer, Kotah City Circle, sent a show cause numberice to the respondent in the following words Your writ No. 11 has been dismissed by the Honble High Court on 23rd November, 1959. You are, therefore, requested to deposit the tax due upto date within a week, failing which necessary action according to law will be taken.

facts.text: Show cause notice served on respondent on December 4, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: This numberice was served on the respondent the same day. The respondent filed a return for the 4th quarter ending October 22, 1957, and Rs. 11, 898.31 was deposited as tax.

facts.text: Respondent filed return for 4th quarter ending October 22, 1957 and deposited Rs. 11,898.31 as tax.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed a return for the 4th quarter ending October 22, 1957, and Rs. 11, 898.31 was deposited as tax. It appears that on January 8, 1960, March 5, 1960 and March 19, 1960, he deposited Rs. 28,607 as tax in respect of the four quarters of the accounting period October 23, 1957 to November 10, 1958.

facts.text: On January 8, 1960, March 5, 1960 and March 19, 1960, respondent deposited Rs. 28,607 as tax for four quarters October 23, 1957 to November 10, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on January 8, 1960, March 5, 1960 and March 19, 1960, he deposited Rs. 28,607 as tax in respect of the four quarters of the accounting period October 23, 1957 to November 10, 1958. It is number clear from the record whether he filed returns on these dates.

facts.text: Not clear from record whether respondent filed returns on January 8, March 5, March 19, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: It is number clear from the record whether he filed returns on these dates. On April 25, 1960, the Sales Tax Officer made an assessment in respect of the accounting period November 3, 1956 to October 22, 1957, and proceeded to impose a penalty of Rs. 400 under s. 16 1  b  of the Rajasthan Sales Tax Act.

facts.text: On April 25, 1960, Sales Tax Officer made assessment for period November 3, 1956 to October 22, 1957 and imposed penalty of Rs. 400 under s.16(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: On April 25, 1960, the Sales Tax Officer made an assessment in respect of the accounting period November 3, 1956 to October 22, 1957, and proceeded to impose a penalty of Rs. 400 under s. 16 1  b  of the Rajasthan Sales Tax Act.

facts.text: Respondent appealed to Deputy Commissioner Sales Tax (Appeals), Kotah, who dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent appealed to Deputy Commissioner Sales Tax  Appeals , Kotah, who dismissed the appeal, holding that the stay order of the High Court did number justify the respondent in number filing the return and depositing the tax in accordance with s. 7 2  of the Rajasthan Sales Tax Act.

facts.text: On December 6, 1960, Sales Tax Officer assessed period October 23, 1957 to November 10, 1958 and imposed penalty of Rs. 1,000 for not depositing tax in time.

anchor.surface_text: On December 6, 1960, the Sales Tax Officer assessed the respondent in respect of the accounting period October 23, 1957 to November 10, 1958, and imposed a penalty of Rs. 1,000 for number depositing the tax in time on the same grounds.

facts.text: Respondent filed petition No. 111 of 1961 under Art. 226 on April 3, 1961 challenging penalty for November 3, 1956 to October 22, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then filed a petition  No. III of 1961  under Art. 226 of the Constitution, on April 3, 1961, challenging the imposition of penalty in respect of the period November 3, 1956 to October 22, 1957, and on April 4, 1961, he filed a petition  No. 172 of 1961  challenging the imposition of penalty in respect of the up.65-5 accounting period October 23, 1957 to November 10, 1958.

facts.text: Respondent filed petition No. 172 of 1961 on April 4, 1961 challenging penalty for October 23, 1957 to November 10, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: and on April 4, 1961, he filed a petition  No. 172 of 1961  challenging the imposition of penalty in respect of the up.65-5 accounting period October 23, 1957 to November 10, 1958. As we have said before, the High Court allowed the petitions.

facts.text: High Court allowed the writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant provisions of the Act read thus S. 7(1) Every dealer liable to pay tax shall furnish returns of his turnover for the prescribed periods in the prescribed form, in the prescribed manner and within the prescribed time, to the assessing authority.

concepts.interpretation: Requires furnishing returns within prescribed time.

anchor.surface_text: Provided that the assessing authority may extend the date for the submission of such returns by any dealer or class of dealers by a period not exceeding fifteen days in the aggregate. Every such return shall be accompanied by a Treasury receipt or receipt of any bank authorised to receive money on behalf of the State Government showing the deposit of the full amount of tax due on the basis of return in the Government Treasury or bank concerned.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3, the charging section, read with s. 5, makes tax payable, i.e., creates a liability to pay the tax. That is the normal function of a charging section in a taxing statute.

anchor.surface_text: There was some discussion before us as to the meaning of the words time allowed but we need not decide in this case whether the words time allowed connote time allowed by an assessing authority or time allowed by a provision in the Rules or the Act, or all these things

holdings.text: there has been no breach of s. 16(1)(b) of the Act, and consequently, the orders imposing the penalties cannot be sustained

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there has been no breach of s. 16 1  b  of the Act, and consequently, the orders imposing the penalties cannot be sustained. According to the terms of s. 16 1  b , there must be a tax due and there must be a failure to pay the tax due within the time allowed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.16(1)(b) requires tax to be 'due' and failure to pay within time allowed; no tax due as not quantified

holdings.text: till the tax payable is ascertained by the assessing authority under S. 10, or by the assessee under s. 7(2), no tax can be said to be due within s. 16(1)(b) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Section 3, the charging section, read with s. 5, makes tax payable, i.e., creates a liability to pay the tax. That is the normal function of a charging section in a taxing statute. But till the tax payable is ascertained by the assessing authority under S. 10, or by the assessee under s. 7 2 , no tax can be said to be due

holdings.reasoning_summary: ss.3 & 5 create liability/payable but 'due' only on quantification via return/deposit under s.7(2) or assessment under s.10

holdings.text: the contention of the learned Advocate-General that the show cause notice dated December 4, 1959, makes tax due is without any substance

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the learned Advocate-General that the show cause notice dated December 4, 1959, makes tax due is without any substance. He was not able to point to any rule or provision of the Act, under which the show cause notice was issued.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No statutory provision or rule makes tax 'due' upon show cause notice; r.31 applies only post-assessment

holdings.text: we are unable to read the stay order as implying that the respondent was obliged to deposit tax for the stay order then would be of no utility to the assessee

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to read the stay order as implying that the respon- dent was obliged to deposit tax for the stay order then would be of no utility to the assessee. Apart from that, the respondent did not file returns till December 1959, and January-March 1960, and S. 7 2 could not be attracted till then.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Stay order required filing returns but not deposit, as that would render stay futile; s.7(2) not triggered without prior return

The Rajasthan Sales Tax Validation Act 43 of 1959, as a validation measure replacing the Ordinance, addresses the issue of procedural defect in the promulgation of the 1955 Rules in the sales tax context.
Ordinance No. 5 of 1959 (c15) validates the Rules, which were questioned for procedural defect in promulgation in issue i2.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there has been no breach of s. 16 1  b  of the Act, and consequently, the orders imposing the penalties cannot be sustained. According to the terms of s. 16 1  b , there must be a tax due and there must be a failure to pay the tax due within the time allowed.
In the result, the appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3, the charging section, read with s. 5, makes tax payable, i.e., creates a liability to pay the tax. That is the normal function of a charging section in a taxing statute. But till the tax payable is ascertained by the assessing authority under S. 10, or by the assessee under s. 7 2 , no tax can be said to be due
In the result, the appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the learned Advocate-General that the show cause notice dated December 4, 1959, makes tax due is without any substance. He was not able to point to any rule or provision of the Act, under which the show cause notice was issued.
In the result, the appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to read the stay order as implying that the respon- dent was obliged to deposit tax for the stay order then would be of no utility to the assessee. Apart from that, the respondent did not file returns till December 1959, and January-March 1960, and S. 7 2 could not be attracted till then.
In the result, the appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.
